FEATURED NEWS

How to Write a Compelling Attorney Profile Page

On law firm websites, the attorney profile pages are often among the highest-trafficked pages, second only to the home page. Even so, too many attorneys neglect this page or leave it looking like a barebones résumé. Justia President Stacy Stern explains the importance of providing a robust attorney profile page, and she describes how to create one or beef up what you currently have, regardless of where you are in your career.

Tech News

Mueller Indicts 13 Russian Nationals Over 2016 Election Interference

In a much-anticipated move, the US Department of Justice announced in February that Special Counsel Robert Mueller had indicted 13 Russian nationals and three Russian entities for allegedly conspiring to defraud the United States, among other charges, in connection with the 2016 presidential election. The indictment describes how the Russian individuals and entities allegedly began their operations as early as 2014, using social media and other technological means to interfere with the election process.

Russia Used Mainstream Media to Manipulate American Voters

According to analysis conducted by Columbia University social-media researcher Jonathan Albright, Russia’s interference in the 2016 presidential election relied heavily on stories produced by major American news sources. In many instances, the stories themselves were generally factually accurate, but Russian Twitter accounts highlighted certain themes in order to bolster Republican Donald Trump and undermine his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.

Uber and Waymo Settle Trade Secrets Suit Over Driverless Cars

Nearly a year after Waymo (formerly part of Google) first accused Uber of plotting to steal its proprietary self-driving car technology, and four days into trial, the two companies agreed on a settlement. The dispute centered on former Google engineer Anthony Levandowski, who was accused of downloading thousands of Google documents related to autonomous-vehicle technology before leaving the company, and whether Uber had known or played any role in the theft and use of this proprietary information when it acquired a company Levandowski founded.

This Crafty Tactic May Let States Get Around the FCC on Net Neutrality

After the Federal Communications Commission repealed net neutrality rules in December, many states have worked to find ways to impose their own version of those rules within their own borders. Some states are using an innovative strategy; rather than regulating the broadband industry directly, they are requiring that state agencies contract only with providers who agree to net neutrality principles. The idea is that because the state agencies are substantial consumers of internet service, this may create pressure on service providers to abide by net neutrality principles for individual consumers, as well.

97% of Cybersecurity Leaders are Evaluating Vendor Security, Including Law Firms, Says New Survey

A report released in February 2018 considers the roles of CISOs (chief information security officers) in managing and safeguarding data, as well as their business vendor auditing practices and the adoption of cloud technology. The report’s findings indicate that ninety-seven percent of leaders in corporate cybersecurity formally assess the security practices of their vendors, including law firms. Despite this level of scrutiny, fifty-three percent of respondents revealed that they were confident the data managed by third party vendors was secure, including information managed by law firms.

Blockchain: Disrupting Industries and Transforming Legal Roles

This article from Above the Law encourages lawyers to learn about blockchain technology, and even to adopt blockchain in their practices, in order to stay on top of revolutionary technology. The author explains the different ways in which blockchain can affect the practice of law, and notes that we cannot even predict all the ways the technology might change the world.

SEO News

Chrome Will Soon Mark All Unencrypted Pages as ‘Not Secure’

Starting in July 2018, Chrome will mark all sites that do not use HTTPS encryption as “not secure” in the address bar. For several years, Google has consistently pushed website owners and developers to use HTTPS to help secure browsing data. While Chrome already flags non-HTTPS pages that have form fields as “not secure,” the changes in July will apply to all non-HTTPS sites, regardless of whether they have form fields on them.

Bing Adds Sentiment Analysis to Search - Google Said to be Next

Microsoft’s internet search engine, Bing, is now offering sentiment analysis technology. This technology involves the ability to determine whether web content has a negative or positive sentiment, and is believed to affect SEO in a variety of ways. Google has also indicated its intention to one day add sentiment analysis into its Featured Snippets, in a move likely meant to allow it to keep pace with Bing’s latest announcement.

Social Media News

The Follower Factor

Everyone wants to be popular on social media, to boast a high number of followers and be seen as a social influencer. The increase in fake accounts that various celebrities, athletes, and politicians count among their followers has become a recent point of interest. Sometimes these fake accounts number in the millions for a single user. Increasingly, social media platforms are grappling with how to respond to a black market that creates fake accounts based off real people’s identities, the creation of which can often be linked to governments, criminals, and entrepreneurs attempting to influence public sentiment.

How Participation Marketing Elevates Your Social Media Strategy

In the ever-evolving business of digital marketing, companies are getting creative and encouraging employees to become advocates for their brand. The reason behind this new trend relates to the belief that employees are more authentic in their assessments of the businesses they work for than business owners themselves. Peer recommendations also appear to increase trust in a company. The practice is most commonly known as “employee advocacy” or “social selling,” and recent research data supports the perceived value behind rallying a business’s employees as media advocates.

The Types of Social Media Video Content You Need to Spark Engagement on Each Major Platform

All social media networks are created equal, right? Not quite. While the competition to attract and maintain customers’ interest is becoming increasingly fierce, and video content continues to increase in popularity across the board, the types of video content that perform best often vary from platform to platform. It becomes useful, then, to know what types of video content are most effective on the social media platforms your business makes use of most often.

Facebook Confirms Test of a Downvote Button for Flagging Comments

Facebook’s ongoing mission to promote meaningful interactions between its users has led to the social media company’s latest effort to develop a downvote button, intended to allow users to flag and hide comments they deem inappropriate or misleading. Testing is currently underway on a limited number of public Page post comments, but the ability to downvote comments deemed unsavory may raise an issue as to free speech censorship by a media company.

NY Top Court Says ‘Private’ Facebook Photos Can be Disclosed

In a recent personal injury lawsuit, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled that Facebook photos shared on a private setting could still be considered discoverable in some instances. While acknowledging that there was “significant controversy” pertaining to what information on Facebook warrants privacy protection, the chief judge indicated that it was appropriate to require the disclosure of materials that contain “material and necessary” evidence or those which are “reasonably calculated” to contain such evidence.

YouTube Suspends Ads on Logan Paul Videos, Citing His ‘Pattern of Behavior’

YouTube temporarily suspended ads on video blogger Logan Paul’s YouTube channels in February. According to a Google spokesperson, the decision was based on a pattern of behavior that Paul displayed in his videos, which made his channel unsuitable for advertisers, as well as potentially harmful to “the broader creator community.” This suspension comes in the midst YouTube’s ongoing attempts to explore consequences for video creators who engage in what it refers to as “egregious behavior.”

Legal Industry News

New Tax Law Affects Alimony, Could Spur Divorce Surge

Experts are predicting an uptick in divorces in 2018, likely due to tax law changes that will go into effect in 2019. A deduction for alimony payments that has been on the books for over 75 years will be wiped out next year under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. Since this change is not expected to affect couples who divorce or sign separation agreements prior to 2019, legal experts are anticipating a surge in divorce filings in 2018.

Legal Employment Drops by 1,100 Jobs in January

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported 1,100 fewer employment opportunities this past January in the US legal sector. This figure dropped even as 200,000 jobs were added during the same time period. The amount of legal sector jobs in January 2018 is still 3,000 higher than in January 2017, meaning the number of those employed in this sector has remained more or less steady for the past couple years, within the same general range of 1.12 million to 1.13 million employed people. Despite the slight increase between 2017 and 2018, this figure is still approximately 50,000 jobs fewer than 2007’s pre-recession numbers of 1.18 million.

Lawyers from Less Privileged Backgrounds Tell Their Stories at #mypathtolaw

Exeter University lecturer Matthew Channon is encouraging lawyers from underprivileged backgrounds to tell their stories on Twitter using the hashtag #mypathtolaw. Channon himself was the first member of his family to attend college, and his movement has encouraged lawyers all over to share their inspiring stories.

Judge Tells Law Firms They Can’t Trademark Initials

A state district judge in Houston recently ruled that a law firm did not have exclusive rights or a common law trademark to the initials in its name. The dispute arose between two personal injury law firms, PM Law Firm and P & M. The former sued the latter, alleging violation of its common law trademark on the initials and confusing clients. As many law firms move toward simpler names, this ruling may serve as a reminder that some names may be too simple.

TIP OF THE MONTH

Add a Narrative Bio to Your Free Justia Lawyer Directory Profile

We recommend adding a well-written biography to your JLD profile that highlights your practice and shows off your passion for the law. While you may discuss your educational and professional experience, this section is really targeted for weaving a narrative about your entire practice so that a potential client can understand you and your law firm in a way that mere biographical facts cannot communicate.
